body:
Got the Outin Nano mainly because I needed a portable machine. While I've had occasional issues with it, its a very well made device that does its job amazingly.
Pros :
1. Because it has an in-built heater, it allows you to make coffee anywhere, and all you need is water and ground coffee.

Cons :

3. Sometimes, it doesn't seal right and it there's no way of knowing it, until you see clear water come out, and not a rich espresso.

Pro tip : Use heated water, the machine has an inbuilt sensor, if the water is not hot enough, it'll use the heater, otherwise it won't. So if at home, you can use hot water, and the battery lasts for almost a 100 cups instead of the usual 3-4 if you use the inbuilt heater only.

Overall, if portability is not a requirement, there are cheaper options out there, but if you want the option to make freshly brewed coffee on a trip, or to share it with friends, this thing is amazing.

title: Outin Nano: Break the Shackles of Corporate Coffee and Explore the Third Wave!
body:
I love flavored espresso, but I don't have access to a good espresso machine nor necessarily need one since I use use enhancers like Monin flavors. That's why I decided to try the Outin Nano, a portable electric espresso maker that claims to brew rich crema espresso with just one tap and is cost effective for my usage.

The Outin Nano is very easy to use and convenient. It weighs less than 700g and fits in my backpack or suitcase. It has a long battery life that allows me to brew espresso for quite literally months since I preheat filtered water in a kettle.

I started out with a cheap grinder from Amazon, but the results were all over the place and I‚Äôd end up with a pool of water. Since picking up the 1Zpresso X-Ultra coffee bean grinder it‚Äôs truly taken the Outin to the next level. I use a setting of 1.2 (one rotation on the 2 tick - in the Aeropress range according to the 1Zpresso manual) as using a fine grind typically used for Espresso results in an awful dishwater-like consistency.

Of course, the Outin Nano is not exactly the same as a real espresso machine. It produces espresso at a much higher bar pressure than the standard 9 bar, which may affect the taste and extraction of some coffee varieties. It also has a limited water capacity of 80ml, which means I can only make two shots of espresso at a time. If I want a larger cup of coffee, I have to make another batch, but given my usage it‚Äôs generally irrelevant.

However, these are minor drawbacks compared to the benefits of having an inexpensive, comparable espresso device . The Outin Nano is a great device for flavored espresso lovers seeking to break free from the shackles of corporate coffee while opening up a world of flavors in the third wave realm. I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a smart and convenient way to brew espresso.

title: Decently built and works as advertised but has long term issues
body:
Decent quality robust build that works as advertised. Either use pods or use the ground coffee pod to insert your own tea, coffee or other herb solution. After using it for a while the battery already starting to show degradation like self discharging, jump from 2 lights to 0 which means potentially dead battery cells. This after roughly 20 uses and 6 charges. Also it doesn't use up all the water which in turn when changing pod there will be coffee that smears around so have a towel around. Putting hot water in the container makes the lid open up and since it doesn't have a lock you can get burnt.

EDIT: It just died on me. Was charged to 2 light markers yesterday but today it was completely discharged. Connected it to the charger and it beeps 2 times (overheating) despite being cool to the touch and starts to charge with first light blinking for 10 seconds then 3 lights lit up and the fourth is blinking but no charge. Seems one of the batteries (3x2500mAh) and/or temperature sensors (3 sensors) gone bad. Looking inside it it all seems alright but there was a leftover plastic strip part under the motherboard making it bulge. I assume this is no "ghetto" solution to make more space between the motherboards underside + plastic holder and battery since there is no risk of short circuit. If this has caused broken solder joints due to vibrations and heat I don't know but it bulged the motherboard quite a bit. 2 stars. At least it made me some coffee although far more costly than ordering at a coffee shop.

title: Battery technology is not quite ready yet.
body:
I wanted to like this device, but after using it for a few shots, I realized it's not ready for prime time.

I was hoping to use this while skiing to get a hot shot of coffee during gondola rides on cold days. However, I don't see the benefit over just carrying a quality thermos of hot coffee. The item is about as large and heavy as a thermos. however, it will stay as heavy all day, while the thermos gets lighter. I was only able to get a couple of shots out of it, before the batter level was too low to produce any more. I imagine the battery performance will only suffer in the cold, as most batteries do. The water reservoir is only good for 80 ml, and is only a fit seal, not a screw seal, so it would likely leak in a backpack. Therefore, you will need to carry a bottle of water too. In the end, it is a lot to lug around the hill for a few tablespoons worth of coffee.

Tips to the manufacturer:

- increase the font size on all the printed materials. I had my readers on and I could still barely read the instructions. The font looks like size 8 or smaller. 12 at a minimum.
- place the instructions for use on the actual device. Whenever using a code of blinking lights and beeps instead of a digital display (understandable here for battery life), there is a learning curve to the code system. A quick-reference sticker that can be removed once the code is learned would be a worthwhile addition. There's no shortage of space on the device for such a sticker.
- capsule removal. There should be an easier way to pop out the spent capsules without needing to pry them out with your fingers. They can be hot, so a button that helps pop them out, or a small prying tool that can be stored on the device would be helpful.
- perhaps place a screw lid on the water reservoir to avoid spilling when transporting with a full reservoir.
- offer a model with a larger reservoir to avoid the need to constantly refill

title: Alright, not espresso but Alright...
body:
What I like: this device works well, using the original style nespresso pods thr more cylindrical not the spherical shaped ones. It is nice to have for portability and if you want to brew coffee on the go.
The device itself is aprox 600grams
It is easy to clean with both coffee grounds or pods, run a little water through it done.
It is easy to use and you literally can have coffee with a press of a button.
The pods give a consistent outcome. The grounds are a bit more challenging. Played with various grind sizes and determined on my grinder extra fine worked best for flavorful extraction.

The issues I have are a few. One the ratio for espresso is 1.5-3 parts water to gram of coffee. The closest you get is with 50ml line a 13:1 ratio. Giving you a bit stronger cup then the recommend 16 or 17 to 1 ratio for Drip. So espresso it is not based on extraction alone.
Next is using the heating of the unit gives you 3 or 4 runs. And there is no temp gage so it appears it heats to aprox 140ish degrees and stops. Which is a super cold brew temp. In my various tests I was not able to exceed 145 degrees. Then the coffee out was between 80-90. So this caused a bit bitter coffee. Would like to see it maintain temp at very least. And since my roast is light to med, recommend temp is 195-205. Long way off from that temp.

All and all it as it's place, nit making espresso but a shot or 2 of coffee. If you have need for it, it works well. I don't camp but will take this with me on trips and to the office as the office pot is always a little sketchy for me. Good product not great.

title: End results amazing! A few issues to be improved
body:
Alright. I'm a lifelong espresso drinker. Every morning. I make my morning latte every day. Someone gave me a Vienna Plus espresso machine and it's saved my life and pocket book.

The biggest problem I've had is when I go camping. I'd been doing those iced coffee Starbucks packets, but they were always so sweet and don't hit the mark for me. On my camping/road trips I spent too much of my budget just making sure I'm caffeinated. And now I'm not giving my money to Starbucks (union busting my friends in Seattle) so I looked for other options.

I thought about upgrading my solar battery to a larger output so I could bring my Vienna Plus espresso machine, but that's ridiculous and big, and also expensive to upgrade to a high enough output. But I was tempted.

Then someone mentioned this Outin compact espresso machine on their outdoorsy YouTube channel. (Modern Self Reliance) I don't think he was sponsored by them, but just wanted to give a review. I put it in my mind bank because it was $140 at the time. Honestly still a reasonable price with the results I have. But then it was on sale for Prime Day at $111. I thought I'd give it a shot (pun intended). They take returns if I don't like it.

Let me tell ya.

I was actually shocked. It might pull better shots than my Saeco Vienna Plus. And the espresso has a more sweet balance, which I like.

Positives. Awesome shots, portable, charges fairly fast, but I recommend charging the night before if you have coffee dysfunction in the morning. It will use most of the battery for 3 shots. Works really well for iced latte.

Negatives. Takes quite a while to heat up between shots (you can preheat the water to shorten this time). You need to watch out when you unload the spent coffee for the next shot because it can be really hot. The set up was confusing per the instructions and I needed to go to YouTube. There was a random piece that didn't seem to be needed and maybe I'll figure that out later. It says it takes Nespresso pods, but I absolutely could not figure out how to fit them in the space nor how it was supposed to puncture the pod, so I just cut open the pod and tamped the espresso directly in the device. At that point I may as well just buy pre-ground espresso for cheaper. Lesson learned. The instructions and pieces need to be color coded because all I can see in the pictures are "put this thing in this black cylindrical piece". Which is almost all of the pieces! Maybe it was my eyesight. Maybe it was my lack of having had coffee. But I can imagine someone with a disability finding this confusing. [Update: When I was fully caffeinated I realized the extra piece was the slot for the pods. D'oh! See, this is why they should be color coded. But crisis averted for the rest of the trip. Which went great except for one particularly cold morning and the water was too cold to heat up the 3 double shots I was pulling. Pre heating the water is a good idea if you can.]

Overall, despite those negatives, I recommend this device for those who have roughed it when going camping and hate that part of camping without a comforting espresso. It's a nice little luxury amongst bugs and the 100¬∞+ weather at Lake Siskiyou that we are being cursed with.

Dare I say I might even be tempted to use this at home as well. Maybe. It does take a lot longer. But I really like the flavor of the shots. Highly impressed!

title: Slick, Smooth - limited uses
body:
This brah is without any doubt really totally undeniably cool looking. It also feels so weighty and hefty and legit in your hands. the brews -- both Nespresso and fresh grounds -- work cleanly and easily. But, just not sure if/when you'd really use this so often, and outside of long trips and/or camping.

1) if using cold water you can make only 4-5 shots on a full charge (and it takes a while to charge)
2) it takes about 5 mins to warm up the warmer if using cold water
3) once down to less then 30% it might die or refuse to make any more when using cold water so its more like 2-3 shots
4) The max water capacity is really just a big shot of espresso -- so dont think you're making anything more than that ... and you'll have to get some legit espresso beans if you're planning to add anything to these (americano etc). Anything less potent and the compartment wont fit enough grounds to water split to enable you to water it down, for example, and still have something tasty.

Ok, so given that -- this suits only a couple of real needs as outlined in the listing. Camping obviously. Where you might be with your SO and one charge will get you both going in the AM, then you hook it up to your generator while out and about, ready to go the next day. It takes a bit of your genny, but not soooo much. And if with a larger group, probably boiling water for brekky anyways, so can handle larger groups as stated above, up to 150 shots!

long drives -- well obviously if you are not solo, someone can brew for you. Or if solo, when you stop if you dont wanna go into the rest stops. With newer cars, just hook it up to the usb charger and you are set. But, keep in mind, this thing needs to be on a pretty flat surface and also cant really be jostled around and moved about while its brewing -- so that might limit its while moving, non stationary uses.

I was going to use this in my day to day to make shots of espresso for red eyes // in my pour over set ups ... but Jesus, for home use, dealing with the grounds is a royal pain. In trying to do this 3 times, I spilled some used grounds twice ... just not worth it. I also stole some Nespresso pods from my neighbor, but honestly -- if im gonna go back to ordering pods all the time, a cheapy machine costs just more than this.

Also, not sure this works as a non home // alt location brewer -- maybe one might snag this for that use, but if you can access boiling water, just assume you can get a better vehicle / access point for any type of java variant this thing can provide.

Also, back to the shots -- the inability to control the amount of water is an issue. The tub at the top holds only a minimal amount. Also, if you take the top off and maybe just pour more water in, that could work, BUT, the cup on the bottom is also tiny -- and if youre like using a larger cup, then one hand is holding that cup and the other hand is pouting ini more water, and a third needs to hold the unit. Sorry, that sounds crazy but Ive given trying to love this thing and use a lot of thought.

pods would make this whole deal more easy, but as mentioned could just get a cheapy machine. Given that I camp like once every 3 years, and when I go to mountain / lake houses etc, we usually have a larger group and an airtight coffee plan already made ... this brah, sadly, will have to wait to be gifted to committed outdoorsy friend or couple I have yet to meet. Ha.
